org.bukkit.craftbukkit.scheduler

Class CraftScheduler

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.bukkit.craftbukkit.scheduler.CraftScheduler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BukkitScheduler

    public class CraftScheduler
extends Object
implements BukkitScheduler
    The fundamental concepts for this implementation:
  • Main thread owns head and currentTick, but it may be read from any thread
  • Main thread exclusively controls temp and pending. They are never to be accessed outside of the main thread; alternatives exist to prevent locking.
  • head to tail act as a linked list/queue, with 1 consumer and infinite producers. Adding to the tail is atomic and very efficient; utility method is handle(CraftTask, long) or addTask(CraftTask).
  • Changing the period on a task is delicate. Any future task needs to notify waiting threads. Async tasks must be synchronized to make sure that any thread that's finishing will remove itself from runners. Another utility method is provided for this, #cancelTask(CraftTask)
  • runners provides a moderately up-to-date view of active tasks. If the linked head to tail set is read, all remaining tasks that were active at the time execution started will be located in runners.
  • Async tasks are responsible for removing themselves from runners
  • Sync tasks are only to be removed from runners on the main thread when coupled with a removal from pending and temp.
  • Most of the design in this scheduler relies on queuing special tasks to perform any data changes on the main thread. When executed from inside a synchronous method, the scheduler will be updated before next execution by virtue of the frequent parsePending() calls.
